Here's a recipe for DIY hand sanitizer. Read completely before starting.
A) 2 cups 70-99% isopropyl alcohol
B) 1.5 cups Aloe Vera gel or 1/4 cup + 1 Tbl glycerin
C) 2 Tbl Hydrogen Peroxide
D) Just enough bottled or boiled water to make 4 cups
E) 4-10 drops of an essential oil you like the smell of.
Mix all ingredients in a glass mason jar or similar item with a lid that has a decent seal. Stir until well mixed then put lid on and shake a couple times. This should be enough for 2-4 weeks.
Label bottles "Hand Sanitizer" before next step.
Pour into a small travel size spray bottle using a funnel. Only use as many bottles as people in your home.
Spray bottles can be reused indefinitely.
Do not make more than 40 oz at a time as the glycerin may break down.
NOTE: If boiled water is used, let cool to room temperature. 2 or 3 sprays on both hands should be enough and remember to rub your hands as though washing them for a few seconds. More than 2 or 3 sprays is a waste and unneeded. Be smart and do not over use. After use make sure hands have dried before touching near the eyes or nose.

Surgical masks are meant to be worn during surgery. That big light above the operating table? That light also contains a filtered air blower, pushing clear air over the operating table. It pushes away air that may contain germs and virusses.

What can it not push away? Spit you release during talking, or sneezing, coughing etc - that is what the masks are for.

30 minutes of use however, those masks on the outside are considered dirty. A surgeon adjusting his mask after that time, would need to exit the room and wash up completely again. Taking off the mask and touching the outside or your face or your hair, also makes your hands dirty - so go wash again.

All of those measures are to prevent the surgical scar / wound from becoming infected. A tiny patch of skin - the rest being covered by covers, all to prevent pathogens to reach into the body.

Masks filter the air, and simply reduce the amount of virus you get in. N95 are much better filters, but only filter about 95% out of the air - so 5% still reaches your lungs. Its then a matter of numbers to how sick you can get.

Keep 6 feet of distance, wash your hands whenever you had a 'risky event' (anything outside your house, and wash your hands upon entering your house). Groceries, deliveries, people who come over or you visit. Church, sports, school, clubs, events -- all of it. First order of business is to wash your hands after closing the front door. Under ideal conditions the virus will remain contageious for 48h on some surfaces. If you get anything home delivered, put it in a corner of the house somewhere, wash your hands, leave it there for a day, and then unpack it.

If possible, wear a coat with long sleeves and touch as many doors / products with your elbows or hands inside of the sleeves. If your coat gets contaminated, no problem - because you should try to only leave the house every few days, by which the virus would ve died on the coat.

Dont buy in bulk - just get groceries once a week, and its fine. Work from home, play in the yard, stay home as much as possible.

Alcohol based hand sanitizers are not the only solution - I recently came across an interesting video about using a compound called "benzalkonium chloride"; it's sold as a moss killer ... I got a 1 litre bottle at 50% concentration (Search E-Bay for "BAC 50"). To use as a hand sanitizer it is very important to dilute it down with water to less than 1% concentration - apparently somewhere in the region of 0.2%. Using it as it comes will cause chemical burns / blistering, so be careful! Once diluted, I added a small amount of glycerine (used in cake-baking amongst other things) which acts as a skin moisturiser - and if you want, also add a small amount of perfume (I used a drop of floral disinfectant), so you smell pretty! The litre bottle cost less than £10 and is enough to make up 250 litres of hand sanitizer. For application, I also got some 50ml pump bottles from E-Bay... Here is a link to the video I saw ... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgY04l0CuEs&ab_channel=bigclivedotcom
Hope this helps some people :-)

Semantic point. Viruses aren't technically alive, so "they can live for...' is misleading, They are 'active' or 'infectious for' is more meaningful. It may sound like a nit pick. but there's a LOT of misinformation about viruses that this reinforces - like the notion that penicillin can be used to prevent or treat Covid-19. It can't. Antibiotics work by disrupting the cell membranes or the internal cellular mechanisms and viruses don't have these.


People also don't have a good grasp on how small most viruses are compared to bacteria. This why regular face masks won't help you avoid it - the virus particles can pass right through unless the mask is rated to filter particles that small and is fit precisely to your face. As the video notes, if you are sick, it can protect everyone else to a degree because it's a little like wearing a bit of sleeve over your mouth all the time, so when you sneeze or cough it gets caught.

It should be explained to people (although it won't be) that virions are not alive in the first place. Bacteria, by contrast, perform the independent reproductive and metabolic processes that define life. A virus is a strand of rna or dna in a sort of chemical 'suitcase.' It is your body, when immunologically compromised in some way, that unzips the suitcase, and reads and executes the genetic instructions. We can therefore fight virus by 1. washing them down the drain (takes some knowledge of how); 2. destroying them (not easy); or 3. bolstering human nutrition and immunity factors so that the virus will not cause illness (easy and supportive of human health in general).  The mistake that will be written about for the next 20 years, at least, is that virtually no attention is being given to #3. People are not being allowed outside their homes, but they are still smoking, drinking, and eating horrible things like fast food. Every one of these things is so horribly immune-negative that if we were to address them, the "curve would be flattened," very quickly, which, after all, is the objective everyone already supports.

For all the suggestions of hand washing and not touching your face, I question how many COVID-19 infections people's increased attempts at hygiene will actually prevent. I've looked at the science linked by the recommendations from the CDC and others and it's good at showing how many log levels of germs you're going to remove and how much it helps in 3rd world countries for bacterial infections. But there's not much in the way of evidence demonstrating how effective it is at preventing this kind of viral infection, because it's a damn hard thing to study. More important than how long you wash is probably HOW you wash your hands and WHEN you wash your hands as far as preventing COVID-19. And I don't want to dissuade anyone from washing their hands as often as appropriate. There are downfalls to doing it too much, but I wouldn't use them to argue against pragmatic hygiene. But I do feel like this is just a suggestion that's being given to us because there isn't much you really CAN do to proactively avoid this virus. A majority of the world will likely end up getting it at some point without a vaccine. It is pretty much social distancing or bust.

I'd like to point out the real usefulness of wearing a mask. Example: you're passing someone on an aisle at the store. They're sick and breathing in your direction, you are inhaling from their direction. Any particles you would have inhaled are blocked. So they ARE effective. Now if you're in a crowded room and particles are being exhaled all over the place, then absolutely they can come in from the gaps in the mask and make it inside you. But breath is warm and moist. As a mist it cools rapidly after exhalation.  Convection and gravity force those heavy, cooling particles downward. So while a mask won't be 100% effective, it is highly effective if you are practicing social distancing. Also, an N95 mask means 95% efficiency at filtering particles. That's not 100%, either. And as always, something is better than nothing
